content.html:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

  1. A new bicycle sells for $300. It is on sale for \(\frac14\) off the regular price. Select all the expressions that represent the sale price of the bicycle in dollars.

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 5.5.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answers are \(300 \cdot \frac34\), \(300 \cdot (1-\frac{1}{4})\), and \(300-\frac{1}{4} \cdot 300\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. A computer costs $800. It loses \(\frac14\) of its value every year after it is purchased.

    Answer the following questions that would complete the table to show the value of the computer at the listed times.

    time (years)

    value of computer (dollars)

    0

    		  

    1

    		  

    2

    		  

    3

    		  

    \(t\)

    		  

    1. The value of the computer, in dollars, when it is purchased.

Correct! 800.

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activities 5.5.1 - 5.5.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is 800. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. The value of the computer, in dollars, after 1 year.

Correct! 600.

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activities 5.5.1 - 5.5.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is 600. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. The value of the computer, in dollars, after 2 years.

Correct! 450.

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activities 5.5.1 - 5.5.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is 450. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. A computer costs $800. It loses \(\frac14\) of its value every year after it is purchased. Which of the following expressions would represent the value of the computer, in dollars, after \(t\) years?      

Correct! \(800 \cdot \frac{3}{4}^t\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 5.5.1 -5.5.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(800 \cdot (\frac{3}{4})^t\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Use your equation from question 3 to find \(v\) when \(t\) is 5. What does this value of \(v\) mean?

Correct! 189.84, After 5 years the computer’s value is $189.84.

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 5.5.5 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is a. 189.84, After 5 years the computer’s value is $189.84. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. A piece of paper is folded into thirds multiple times. The area, \(A\), of the piece of paper in square inches, after \(n\) folds, is \(A=90 \cdot (\frac{1}{3})^n\).

    1. What is the value of \(A\) when \(n=0\)? What does this mean in this situation?

Correct! 90. That is the area of the paper in square inches before it is folded.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 5.5.5. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 90. That is the area of the paper in square inches before it is folded. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. How many folds are needed before the area is less than 1 square inch?

Correct! 5.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 5.5.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 5. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. The area of another piece of paper in square inches, after \(n\) folds, is given by \(A=100 \cdot (\frac{1}{2})^n\). What does the number 100 mean in this situation?

Correct! The area before the paper is folded. The a value in y=abx is always the initial value

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 5.5.5 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is: The area before the paper is folded. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. The area of another piece of paper in square inches, after \(n\) folds, is given by \(A=100 \cdot (\frac{1}{2})^n\). What does the number \(\frac12\) mean in this situation?

Correct! The growth factor of the situation.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 5.5.5. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: The growth factor of the situation. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Lin has 13 mystery novels. Each month, she gets 2 more. Select all expressions that represent the total number of mystery novels Lin has after 3 months.

Correct! 13 + 2 + 2+ 2, 13 + 6, 19.

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 5.5.1 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answers are 13 + 2 + 2+ 2, 13 + 6, 19. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. The graph shows the amount of a chemical in a water sample. It is decreasing exponentially.

    1. What are the coordinates of point \(A\)?

Correct! (2, 640).

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 5.5.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is (2, 640). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. What are the coordinates of point \(B\)?

Correct! (3, 512).

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 5.5.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is (3, 512). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. Which of the following equations would represent the chemical, \(C\), after time, \(t\), from the graph?

Correct! \(C = 1000(\frac{4}{5})^x\).

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 5.5.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(C = 1000(\frac{4}{5})^x\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. The graph shows the amount of a chemical in a water sample at different times after it was first measured. Select all statements that are true.

Correct!

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 5.5.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answers are a and d. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. The height of a plant in mm is 7. It doubles each week. Select all expressions that represent the height of the plant, in mm, after 4 weeks.

Correct! \( 7 \cdot 2^4\), \( 7 \cdot 2 \cdot 2 \cdot 2 \cdot 2\).

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 5.5.1. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answers are \(7 \cdot 2^4\) and \( 7 \cdot 2 \cdot 2 \cdot 2 \cdot 2\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?
